choices.text: Stones are most commonly composed of Calcium phosphate
pH of <7 predisposes to formation of struvite stones
CT with radiation dose of 3mSv is currently the preferred imaging study for patients with a body mass index (BMI) <30.
Alpha blockers have to be useful in patients with distal ureteric calculus of size ≤ 12mm.

questions.text: All of the following regarding Urolithiasis are false except ?
questions.solution:
• Option a) Stones are most commonly composed of calcium oxalate.
  • Option b) The alkaline milieu (pH >7) predisposes to infectious (struvite) stones with the precipitation of magnesium, ammonium, and phosphate
  • Option c) is correct : Low-dose CT is currently the preferred imaging study for patients with a body mass index (BMI)<30. This imaging study uses less than one-third of the estimated effective ionizing radiation dose (3 mSv) compared to standard dose noncontrast CT (10 mSv), 10 while maintaining excellent sensitivity (95%) and specificity (97%).
  • Option d) α-Blockers, which inhibit ureteral peristalsis, have been shown in meta-analyses to be particularly useful in patients with distal ureter stones ≤10 mm, improving the rate of stone passage from 54% to 77%, with shortened time to expulsion and fewer colic episodes.

Reference: (Schwartz 11edition,page No 1762)

questions.text: What is the overall surgical mortality rates to be considered in a 50 year old male jaundiced (T.bilirubin 5mg/dl) patient case of Liver cirrhosis with moderate ascites with no encephalopathy at present Patient also has a Albumin of 2.6g/dl, PT/NR of about 6/2.3 ?
questions.solution:
This patient comes in Class C as per the Child-Turcotte-Pugh Score.


  • Numerous studies have demonstrated overall surgical mortality rates of 10% for patients with class A cirrhosis, 30% for those with class B cirrhosis, and 75% to 80% for those with class C cirrhosis.

Reference: (Schwartz 11edition,Page No. 1365)

choices.text: MELD score requires S.Creatinine, S.Total Bilirubin and INR for its calculation.
Carbon-13 aminopyrine breath test has been disappointing in assessing hepatic reserve in patients with liver cirrhosis
Patient's with MELD score below 15 can undergo elective surgery safely
MEGX test is not useful in diagnosing cirrhosis in patients having S.Bilirubin higher than normal.

questions.text: All of the following are true except ?
questions.solution:
• Option a) MELD Score = 9.57 Ln(SCr) + 3.78 Ln(Tbil) + 11.2 Ln(INR) + 6.43
  • where Ln represents natural logarithm, SCr is serum creatinine level (in milligrams per deciliter), and Tbil is serum bilirubin level (in milligrams per deciliter)
  • Option b) Tests of indocyanine green, sorbitol, and galactose elimination capacity as well as the carbon-13 galactose breath test and carbon-13 aminopyrine breath test have all been disappointing clinically due to their dependence on flow to the liver as well as the unavailability and complexity of the tests
  • Option c) it has been proposed that patients with a MELD score below 10 can safely undergo elective surgery, those with MELD between 10 and 15 may undergo surgery with caution, while those with MELD scores in excess of 15 should not be subjected to elective surgical procedures
  • Option d) The monoethylglycinexylidide (MEGX) test, which measures MEGX formation after the administration of lidocaine, has been shown to be approximately 80% sensitive and specific in diagnosing cirrhosis.
  • However, this test loses both sensitivity and specificity as the serum bilirubin level rises and interferes with the fluorescent readout system.

choices.text: Exploration and repair of the bladder in emergency

questions.text: A 26 year old male suffered from RTA and complained of inability to pass urine. A CT cystogram was performed and is as follows.What will be the management in this patient ?
questions.solution:
• In the above image, extravesical contrast is seen contained within the extraperitoneal space at the red arrow.
  • Two general categories of bladder injuries are extraperitoneal and intraperitoneal injuries. An intraperitoneal injury requires repair during the index admission after the patient has been resuscitated.
  • Delayed repairs are associated with abdominal sepsis. Conversely, extra peritoneal injuries can generally be managed with Foley catheter drainage alone.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
• Priapism
  • A surgical shunt is sometimes necessary to resolve the episode if phenylephrine fails. Distal (corporoglanular) shunts should be performed first because they are the easiest to perform and the lowest amount of complications.
  • A Winter shunt uses a large biopsy needle to create holes between the glans and corpora; however, if this fails, an operative procedure can be performed to remove the distal tips from each corpora (Al-Ghorab)
  • Proximal shunts such as Grayhack (corporal-saphenous vein) or Quackel (proximal cavernosumspongiosum) shunts may be required in refractory cases.

questions.text: A 25 year old male presented to the casualty with complaint of persistent tumescence since last 4 hrs. He gives history of sexual activity after which there was no penile detumescence.ABG of blood taken from penile region revealed normal pO2 levels and no signs of ischemia.Erection is not painful. How will you manage this patient ?
questions.solution:
• The other form of priapism (high-flow/traumatic priapism) is rare and is related to penile or perineal trauma resulting in a cavernous artery-corporal body fistula.
  • This form is not painful because it is not related to ischemia and can be managed conservatively with observation. Many cases will resolve with time; those that do not can undergo selective arterial embolization.

questions.text: A 32 year old male suffered from RTA. questions.solution:
• Compliance is problematic in the long term but, as the risk of overwhelming sepsis is greatest within the first 2-3 years after splenectomy, it seems reasonable to give prophylaxis during this time.

questions.text:
A 35 year old female was brought to emergency with severe pain in the right upper quadrant with fever with chills since last 4 days.Patient is a newly diagnosed case of diabetes mellitus on oral hypoglycemics which she has not taken since last one week. Patient has tenderness and guarding present in the right hypochondriac region with pulse of 106/min, Bp-90/60 mmHg. Patient's CECT(A+P) was done. An axial cut is as follows.

Identify the condition
questions.solution:
• Computed tomography scan of emphysematous cholecystitis. Significant pericholecystic inflammatory changes and air in the gallbladder wall (arrows) are signs of emphysematous cholecystitis.
  • Acute cholecystitis is the result of a blockage of the cystic duct and is called acute calculous cholecystitis when the blockage is by a stone.
  • Obstruction is followed by infection of the stagnant pool of bile. Without resolution of the obstruction, the gallbladder will progress to ischemia and necrosis.
  • Eventually, acute cholecystitis becomes acute gangrenous cholecystitis and, when complicated by infection with a gas-forming organism, acute emphysematous cholecystitis.

questions.text: Match the following

• Other forms of gastritis
  • Eosinophilic gastritis appears to have an allergic basis, and is treated with steroids and cromoglycate. Granulomatous gastritis is seen rarely in Crohn's disease and also may be associated with tuberculosis.
  • Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) gastritis is secondary to infection with cryptosporidiosis.
  • Phlegmonous gastritis is a rare bacterial infection of the stomach found in patients with severe intercurrent illness. It is usually an agonal event.

choices.text: The usual first line of therapy is oral prednisone at a dosage of 1.0 to 1.5 mg/kg per day,response mostly seen within the first 3 weeks
IV immunoglobulin, given at 1.0 g/kg per day for 2 to 3 days, is indicated for internal bleeding when platelet counts remain less than 50000/mm3

Prolonged use of steroids can be defined in various ways, but a persistent need for more than 10 to 20 mg/d for 3 to 6 months to maintain a platelet count of greater than 30,000/mm3 generally prompts referral for splenectomy.
Splenectomy is an effective option for refractory ITP and provides a permanent response without subsequent need for steroids in 75% to 85% of patients

questions.text:
A 42 year old male came to vague abdominal complaints like intermittent dull aching pain since long time,nausea and change in the bowel habits in the recent past.On examination Tillaux sign is positive. On Per rectal examination, anal tone was normal and no evidence of ballooning was noted nor there was any melena noted. Patient's CECT A+P was done, axial cut is shown below.

Diagnose the condition
questions.solution:
• Mesenteric cysts are a rare benign disorder with an incidence ranging from 1 in 27,000 to 1 in 250,000 admissions. Cysts are thought to be caused by disruption of the lymphatics in the mesentery either by traumatic disruption, mechanical obstruction, or congenital lymphatic malformations. Most cysts are unilocular, but they also may have multiple loculations
  • Chronic symptoms are usually nonspecific, including abdominal pain or discomfort, anorexia, distension, nausea, vomiting, or changes in bowel habits. Symptoms are due to local compression of abdominal structures. Up to 45% of cysts are found incidentally.
  • Physical exam revels an abdominal mass in up to 60% of patients. The classic Tillaux's sign is an abdominal mass lesion that is only mobile laterally, contrasting omental cysts which are usually freely mobile in all directions.
  • CT scan and ultrasound can be used to make an accurate diagnosis. Cystic lesions usually appear as a fluid filled mass without solid components

Reference: (Schwartz 11 edition, page number 1560)

questions.text: A 16 year old female was brought to casualty with severe pain in abdomen with reduced appetite and nausea since last 1 day.She had recently observed a month long fast in the period of Ramzan.Her CECT A+P was done,axial image is shown below.Identify the condition
questions.solution:
• Intussusception refers to a condition where one segment of the intestine becomes drawn in to the lumen of the distal segment of the bowel.
  • It is usually seen in the paediatric population the ileum intussuscepts into the cecum (ileocolic intussusception).
  • In children, it is often an idiopathic condition and treated nonsurgically by radiological reduction.
  • CT scan is the investigation of choice, where a 'target sign' may be seen (Fig. 28-32)

Reference:(Schwartz 11 edition, page number 1253)

choices.text: Defined as the presence of less than 200 cm of residual small bowel in adult patients.
Among adult patients who have a functional colon, lifelong TPN dependence is likely to persist if there is less than 100 cm of residual small intestine.
Resection of ileum is better tolerated than resection of jejunum
Kidney failure is a significant source of morbidity and often leads to kidney transplantation.

questions.text: All of the following are false regarding short bowel syndrome except ?
questions.solution:
• Option a) is correct
  • Option b) Among adult patients who lack a functional colon, lifelong TPN dependence is likely to persist if there is less than 100 cm of residual small intestine. Among adult patients who have an intact and functional colon, lifelong TPN dependence is likely to persist if there is less than 60 cm of residual small intestine.
  • Option c) resection of jejunum is better tolerated than resection of ileum, as the capacity for bile salt and vitamin B12 absorption is specific to the ileum
  • Option d) During the period of adaptation, generally lasting 1 to 2 years postoperatively, TPN and enteral nutrition are titrated to allow for independence from TPN. Patients who remain dependent on TPN face substantial TPN-associated morbidities including catheter sepsis, venous thrombosis, liver and kidney failure, and osteoporosis.
  • Liver failure is a significant source of morbidity and often leads to liver transplantation (always in combination with small bowel transplantation).

Reference:(Schwartz 11e, Pg No. 1254,1255)

choices.text: GIST tumours detected on endoscopy less than 2cms with irregular borders and ulcerations can be observed

The Scandinavian Sarcoma Group XVIII trial concluded a 3-year course as the standard of care after surgical resection of high-risk GIST

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding Stomach GIST tumour except ?
questions.solution:
• Option a) The mainstay of treatment is complete surgical resection. Tumors that are symptomatic or greater than 2 cm in diameter should be resected, but the treatment for smaller tumors is controversial.
  • Tumors that are less than 2 cm but which have highrisk features on endoscopy and EUS, such as irregular borders, ulceration, echogenic foci, and heterogeneity, should be resected, whereas tumors without such features can be observed with repeat endoscopy and EUS at 6- to 12-month intervals.

questions.text: All of the following are false regarding Pyelonephritis except ?

  • Option d) Pyelonephritis most often presents between 20 and 28 weeks of gestation with malaise, fever, loin pain and rigors.

choices.text: Acute prostatitis is commonly caused due to E.Coli

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding Prostatitis except?
questions.solution:
• Antibiotic therapy should be administered only in accordance with bacteriological sensitivity tests. Trimethoprim or ciprofloxacin penetrate well into the prostate.
  • If Trichomonas or anaerobes are the responsible agent, a rapid response is obtained from administration of metronidazole (200 mg t.d.s. for 7 days to both partners).
  • If Chlamydia is suspected, doxycycline is the antibiotic treatment of choice. There is little evidence that prostatic massage helps in eradicating the infection.

questions.text: A 40 year old married female with history of burns has come to your opd with inability to use her upper limb effectively. The image of her upper limb is shown below.What treatment will this female be offered ?
questions.solution:
• Where scars cross joints or flexion creases, a tight web may form restricting the range of movement at the joint. This may be referred to as a contracture and can cause hyperextension or hyperflexion deformity.
  • In the neck, it may interfere with head extension. Treatment may be simple involving, multiple Z-plasties, or more complex, requiring the inset of grafts or flaps.
  • Splintage and intensive physiotherapy are often required postoperatively.

questions.text: A 40 year old male patient suffering from urinary bladder malignancy had to undergo ureterosigmoid diversion of urine.What metabolic changes will be expected in this patient ?
questions.solution:
• The biochemical changes associated with urinary diversion are due to a combination of reabsorption of chloride and urea and progressively diminishing tubular function as a result of pyelonephritis.
  • Diarrhoea with loss of potassium-containing mucus may exacerbate the loss of potassium. The typical changes of a hyperchloraemic acidosis with potassium depletion occur more frequently with ureterosigmoid diversion than with a colonic and ileal neobladder.

questions.text: A 50 year old male presented to the opd with a complaints of blood in stools, loss of appetite and loss of weight. He also had a CT report which was suggestive of growth extending to the extrarectal tissues, but without involvement of the regional lymph nodes. There is no evidence of distant metastasis. questions.solution:
• Stages of progression Dukes classified carcinoma of the rectum into three stages.

Dukes staging

  • A: The growth is limited to the rectal wall (15%). The prognosis is excellent (>90% 5-year survival).
  • B: The growth extends to the extrarectal tissues, but without metastasis to the regional lymph nodes (35%). The prognosis is reasonable (70% 5-year survival).
  • C: There are secondary deposits in the regional lymph nodes (50%). These are subdivided into C1, in which the local pararectal lymph nodes alone are involved, and C2, in which the nodes accompanying the supplying blood vessels to their origin from the aorta are involved. This does not take into account cases that have metastasised

Reference: (Bailey & Love 27th edition, Page number 1330-1331)

questions.text: In which cases development of Kasabach Merrit Syndrome is an indication for resection ?
questions.solution:
• An asymptomatic patient with a secure diagnosis can therefore be simply observed. Symptomatic patients should undergo a thorough evaluation looking for alternative explanations for the symptoms but are candidates for resection if no other cause is found.
  • Rupture, significant change in size, and development of the Kasabach-Merritt syndrome are indications for resection.

Reference (Sabiston 21 st edition, Page number 1465)

choices.text: Polyps more than 2 cm should be excised
Any polyp larger than 1.5 cm should be removed if possible

questions.text: A 16 year old male has come to the opd with complaint of blood in stools and mucus in stools. He has brown macule in the vermillion border of the lips. His father had history of Colon Cancer and even father had mucocutaneous pigmentation very much similar to that of the patient. On proctoscopy polyps were found. What is the recommendation for polypectomy in this patient ?
questions.solution:
• This patient is most probably suffering from Peutz-Jegher Syndrome
  • PJS is a clinical diagnosis based on any one of the following World Health Organization criteria:
  • (1) three or more histologically confirmed Peutz-Jeghers polyps;
  • (2) any number of PJ polyps with a family history of PJS;
  • (3) characteristic, prominent, mucocutaneous pigmentation with a family history of PJS; or
  • (4) any number of Peutz-Jeghers polyps and characteristic prominent, mucocutaneous pigmentation
  • Polypectomy plays a key role in the management of PJS. Asymptomatic gastric or colonic polyps larger than 1 cm should be removed endoscopically.
  • Small bowel polyps larger than 1 to 1.5 cm or those that are have grown rapidly should be removed to decrease future complications such as bleeding and intussusception.

Reference: (Sabiston 21st edition, page number 1372)
